The ten grounds are the realizations of Superior Bodhisattvas: Very Joyful, Stainless, Luminous, Radiant, Difficult to Overcome, Approaching, Gone Afar, Immovable, Good Intelligence, and Cloud of Dharma. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Path/Spiritual">Path/Spiritual path</a> path. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Guhyasamaja"><strong>Guhyasamaja</strong> A Highest Yoga Tantra Deity. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="8217;s-Way-of-Life" class="#Guide-to-the-Bodhisattva&amp;"><strong>Guide to the Bodhisattva’s Way of Life</strong> A classic Mahayana Buddhist text composed by the great Indian Buddhist Yogi and scholar Shantideva, which presents all the practices of a Bodhisattva from the initial generation of bodhichitta through to the completion of the practice of the six perfections. For a translation, see <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/guide-to-the-bodhisattvas-way-of-life">Guide to the Bodhisattva’s Way of Life</a>. For a full commentary, see <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Guru"><strong>Guru</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#root-guru">Root Guru and Spiritual Guide</a>.</p>
<p id="Guru-yoga"><strong>Guru yoga</strong> A special way of relying upon our Spiritual Guide in order to receive his or her blessings. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>.</p>
<p id="Gyaltsabje"><strong>Gyaltsabje (AD 1364-1432)</strong> One of the principal disciples of Je Tsongkhapa. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="228;pa" class="#Gyalwa-Ens&amp;"><strong>Gyalwa Ensäpa (AD 1505-1566)</strong> A great Yogi and Mahamudra lineage Guru who attained enlightenment in three years. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Happiness"><strong>Happiness</strong> There are two types of happiness: mundane and supramundane. Mundane happiness is the limited happiness that can be found within samsara, such as the happiness of human beings and gods. Supramundane happiness is the pure happiness of liberation and enlightenment.</p>
<p id="Harmfulness"><strong>Harmfulness</strong> A deluded mental factor that wishes other sentient beings to suffer. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Hashang"><strong>Hashang</strong> A Chinese monk of the twelfth century who propagated many wrong views in Tibet, including the view that the meaning of Buddha’s teachings on emptiness was that we should empty our mind of all conceptions and meditate on nothingness. He was publicly defeated in debate by Kamalashila and banished from Tibet. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Hearer"><strong>Hearer</strong> One of two types of Hinayana practitioner. Both Hearers and Solitary Conquerors are Hinayanists, but they differ in their motivation, behaviour, merit, and wisdom. In all these respects, Solitary Conquerors are superior to Hearers. Hearers are of eight types according to the level of delusions they have abandoned. (1) approachers to the accomplishment of a Stream Enterer, (2) abiders in the accomplishment of a Stream Enterer, (3) approachers to the accomplishment of a Once Returner, (4) abiders in the accomplishment of a Once Returner, (5) approachers to the accomplishment of a Never Returner, (6) abiders in the accomplishment of a Never Returner, (7) approachers to the accomplishment of a Foe Destroyer, and (8) abiders in the accomplishment of a Foe Destroyer. A Stream Enterer is on the path of seeing and will never again be reborn in the three lower realms; a Once Returner will return to the desire realm only once more; and a Never Returner will never again return to the desire realm. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Heart-channel- wheel"><strong>Heart channel wheel</strong> The channel wheel (Skt. chakra) at our heart. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Heart-Sutra"><strong>Heart Sutra</strong> One of several Perfection of Wisdom Sutras that Buddha taught. Although much shorter than the other Perfection of Wisdom Sutras, it contains explicitly or implicitly their entire meaning. Also known as the Essence of Wisdom Sutra. For a full commentary, see <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Hell-realm"><strong>Hell realm</strong> The lowest of the six realms of samsara. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Heruka"><strong>Heruka</strong> A principal Deity of Mother Tantra, who is the embodiment of indivisible bliss and emptiness. He has a blue-coloured body, four faces, and twelve arms, and embraces his consort Vajravarahi. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/essence-of-vajrayana">Essence of Vajrayana</a>.</p>
<p id="Hevajra"><strong>Hevajra</strong> A principal Deity of Mother Tantra. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Hidden-object"><strong>Hidden object</strong> An object whose initial realization by a valid cognizer depends upon correct logical reasons. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Highest-Yoga-Tantra"><strong>Highest Yoga Tantra</strong> The supreme quick path to enlightenment. The teachings on Highest Yoga Tantra are Buddha’s ultimate intention. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Four-classes-of-Tantra">Four classes of Tantra</a>) and <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Tantra">Tantra</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/mahamudra-tantra">Mahamudra Tantra</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Hinayana"><strong>Hinayana</strong> Sanskrit term for <strong>Lesser Vehicle</strong>. The Hinayana goal is to attain merely one’s own liberation from suffering by completely abandoning delusions. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Holding-false-views-as-supreme"><strong>Holding false views as supreme</strong> A deluded view that holds a false view to be correct and superior to other views. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Holding-wrong-moral-disciplines-and-conduct-as-supreme"><strong>Holding wrong moral disciplines and conduct as supreme</strong> A deluded view that holds any wrong moral discipline or conduct to be correct and considers it to be superior to other forms of moral discipline or conduct. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Holy-being"><strong>Holy being</strong> A being who is worthy of devotion</p>
<p id="Humility"><strong>Humility</strong> A virtuous mental factor whose main function is to reduce deluded pride.</p>
<p id="Hundreds-of-Deities-of-the-Joyful-Land"><strong>Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land</strong> <em>Ganden Lhagyäma</em> in Tibetan. A special Guru yoga of Je Tsongkhapa in which Je Tsongkhapa and his two Sons are invited from the Joyful Land, or Tushita. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>.</p>
<p class="Hungry-spirit"><strong>Hungry spirit</strong> A being of the hungry spirit realm, the second lowest of the six realms of samsara. Also known as ‘Hungry ghost’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Ignorance"><strong>Ignorance</strong> A mental factor that is confused about the ultimate nature of phenomena. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Self-grasping">Self-grasping</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind.</a></p>
<p id="Illusory-body"><strong>Illusory body</strong> The subtle divine body that is principally developed from the indestructible wind. When a practitioner of Highest Yoga Tantra rises from the meditation of the isolated mind of ultimate example clear light, he or she attains a body that is not the same as his or her ordinary physical body. This new body is the illusory body. It has the same appearance as the body of the personal Deity of generation stage except that it is white in colour. It can be perceived only by those who have already attained an illusory body. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Impermanent-phenomenon"><strong>Impermanent phenomenon</strong> Phenomena are either permanent or impermanent. `Impermanent’ means `momentary’; thus an impermanent phenomenon is a phenomenon that is produced and disintegrates within a moment. Synonyms of impermanent phenomenon are `functioning thing’, ‘thing’, and `product’. There are two types of impermanence: gross and subtle. Gross impermanence is any impermanence that can be seen by an ordinary sense awareness – for example the ageing and death of a sentient being. Subtle impermanence is the momentary disintegration of a functioning thing. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Imprint"><strong>Imprint</strong> There are two types of imprint: imprints of actions and imprints of delusions. Every action we perform leaves an imprint on the mental consciousness, and these imprints are karmic potentialities to experience certain effects in the future. The imprints left by delusions remain even after the delusions themselves have been abandoned, rather as the smell of garlic lingers in a container after the garlic has been removed. Imprints of delusions are obstructions to omniscience, and are completely abandoned only by Buddhas.</p>
<p id="Imputation"><strong>Imputation</strong>, mere According to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school, all phenomena are merely imputed by conception in dependence upon their basis of imputation. Therefore, they are mere imputation and do not exist from their own side in the least. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Imputed-object"><strong>Imputed object</strong> An object imputed by the mind in dependence upon its basis of imputation. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Inappropriate-attention"><strong>Inappropriate attention</strong> A mind that focuses on the qualities of a contaminated object and exaggerates them. It is what actually generates delusions. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Inconsideration"><strong>Inconsideration</strong> A deluded mental factor that is the opposite of consideration. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Indestructible-drop"><strong>Indestructible drop</strong> The most subtle drop, which is located at the heart. It is formed from the essence of the white and red drops received from our parents at conception, and encloses the very subtle mind and its mounted wind. These red and white drops do not separate until the time of death, when they open and allow the very subtle mind and its mounted wind to depart to the next life. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>.</p>
<p id="Indra"><strong>Indra</strong> A worldly god. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Inferential-cognizer"><strong>Inferential cognizer</strong> A completely reliable cognizer whose object is realized in direct dependence upon a conclusive reason. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Inferential-valid-cognizer"><strong>Inferential valid cognizer</strong> A non-deceptive cognizer that realizes its hidden object by depending upon a conclusive reason. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Inherent-existence"><strong>Inherent existence</strong> An imagined mode of existence whereby phenomena are held to exist from their own side, independent of other phenomena. In reality, all phenomena lack or are empty of inherent existence because they depend upon their parts. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Initial-scope-practitioner"><strong>Initial scope practitioner</strong> A spiritual practitioner who seeks the happiness of humans and gods. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Innate-delusions"><strong>Innate delusions</strong> Delusions that are not the product of intellectual speculation, but that arise naturally. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Inner-Dakini-Land"><strong>Inner Dakini Land</strong> A mind of clear light that realizes emptiness directly without a generic image. Synonymous with meaning clear light. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Inner-fire"><strong>Inner fire</strong> ‘Tummo’ in Tibetan. An inner heat located at the centre of the navel channel wheel. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>.</p>
<p id="Inner-offering"><strong>Inner offering</strong> A Highest Yoga Tantra offering that is produced by transforming ten inner substances into nectar. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Inner-winds"><strong>Inner winds</strong> Special subtle winds related to the mind that flow through the channels of our body. Our body and mind cannot function without these winds. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Intellectually-formed-delusions"><strong>Intellectually-formed delusions</strong> Delusions that arise as a result of relying upon incorrect reasoning or mistaken tenets. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Intention"><strong>Intention</strong> A mental factor that functions to move its primary mind to the object. It functions to engage the mind in virtuous, non-virtuous, and neutral objects. All bodily and verbal actions are initiated by the mental factor intention. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Intermediate-scope-practitioner"><strong>Intermediate scope practitioner</strong> A spiritual practitioner who emphasizes the attainment of his or her liberation from samsara. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Intermediate-state"><strong>Intermediate state</strong> ‘Bardo’ in Tibetan. The state between death and rebirth. It begins the moment the consciousness leaves the body, and ceases the moment the consciousness enters the body of the next life. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>.</p>
<p id="Investigation"><strong>Investigation</strong> A mental factor that examines an object to gain an understanding of its gross nature. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/en/books/understanding-the-mind/">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Ishvara"><strong>Ishvara</strong> A god who abides in the Land of Controlling Emanations, the highest state of existence within the desire realm. Ishvara has limited, contaminated miracle powers that make him more powerful than other beings in the desire realm. If we entrust ourself to Ishvara we may receive some temporary benefit in this life, such as an increase in wealth or possessions, but wrathful Ishvara is the enemy of those who seek liberation and he interferes with their spiritual progress. He is therefore said to be a type of <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Devaputra">Devaputra</a> mara.</p>
<p id="Jealousy"><strong>Jealousy</strong> A deluded mental factor that feels displeasure when observing others’ enjoyments, good qualities, or good fortune. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/en/books/understanding-the-mind/">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Je-Phabongkhapa "><strong>Je Phabongkhapa (AD 1878-1941)</strong> A great Tibetan Lama who was an emanation of Heruka. Phabongkha Rinpoche was the holder of many lineages of Sutra and Secret Mantra. He was the root Guru of <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Trijang-Rinpoche">Yongdzin Trijang Dorjechang</a> (Trijang Rinpoche).</p>
<p id="Je-Tsongkhapa"><strong>Je Tsongkhapa (AD 1357-1419</strong> An emanation of the Wisdom Buddha Manjushri, whose appearance in fourteenth-century Tibet as a monk, and the holder of the lineage of pure view and pure deeds, was prophesied by Buddha. He spread a very pure Buddhadharma throughout Tibet, showing how to combine the practices of Sutra and Tantra, and how to practise pure Dharma during degenerate times. His tradition later became known as the `Gelug’, or `Ganden Tradition’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>:.</p>
<p id="Joyful Land"><strong>Joyful Land</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Ganden">Ganden</a>.</p>
<p id="Kadam-Emanation-Scripture"><strong>Kadam Emanation Scripture</strong> Also known as `Ganden Emanation Scripture’. A special scripture, the nature of Manjushri’s wisdom, revealed directly to Je Tsongkhapa by Manjushri. It contains instructions on Vajrayana Mahamudra, Offering to the Spiritual Guide (Lama Chöpa), The Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land (Ganden Lhagyäma), the Migtsema prayer, and six sadhanas of Manjushri. This scripture was not composed in ordinary letters, and only highly realized beings can consult it directly. At first the instructions from this scripture were passed down only by word of mouth from Teacher to disciple, and so the lineage became known as the `Uncommon Whispered Lineage of the Virtuous Tradition’ or the ‘Ensa Whispered Lineage’. It is also known as the `Uncommon Close Lineage’ because it was revealed directly to Je Tsongkhapa by Manjushri. Later, scholars such as the first <strong>Panchen Lama (AD 1569-1662)</strong> wrote down the instructions from this scripture in ordinary letters. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>.</p>
<p id="Kadampa"><strong>Kadampa</strong> A Tibetan word in which ‘Ka’ means ‘word’ and refers to all Buddha’s teachings, ‘dam’ refers to Atisha’s special Lamrim instructions known as the ‘stages of the path to enlightenment’, and ‘pa’ refers to a follower of Kadampa Buddhism who integrates all the teachings of Buddha that they know into their Lamrim practice. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kadampa-Buddhism">Kadampa Buddhism</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kadampa-Tradition">Kadampa Tradition</a>.</p>
<p id="Kadampa-Buddhism"><strong>Kadampa Buddhism</strong> A Mahayana Buddhist school founded by the great Indian Buddhist Master Atisha (AD 982-1054). See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kadampa">Kadampa</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kadampa-Tradition">Kadampa Tradition</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#New-Kadampa-Tradition">New Kadampa Tradition</a>.</p>
<p id="Kadampa-Tradition"><strong>Kadampa Tradition</strong> The pure tradition of Buddhism established by Atisha. Followers of this tradition up to the time of Je Tsongkhapa are known as `Old Kadampas’, and those after the time of Je Tsongkhapa are known as `New Kadampas’. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kadampa">Kadampa</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kadampa-Buddhism">Kadampa Buddhism</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#New-Kadampa-Tradition">New Kadampa Tradition</a>.</p>
<p id="Kalachakra"><strong>Kalachakra</strong> A Highest Yoga Tantra Deity manifested by Buddha Vajradhara.</p>
<p id="Kalarupa"><strong>Kalarupa</strong> A Dharma Protector who is an emanation of Manjushri.</p>
<p id="Kangyur"><strong>Kangyur</strong> The collection of all the Sutras and Tantras that have been translated from Sanskrit into Tibetan. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Tangyur">Tängyur</a>.</p>
<p id="Karma"><strong>Karma</strong> Sanskrit word meaning ‘action’. Through the force of intention, we perform actions with our body, speech, and mind, and all of these actions produce effects. The effect of virtuous actions is happiness and the effect of negative actions is suffering. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Karmic-appearance"><strong>Karmic appearance</strong> Mere appearance to mind that arises from karma. Everything we perceive when we are dreaming is the result of the ripening of karmic potentials in our mind and has no existence outside of our mind. In a similar way, all the appearances of our waking world are simply the ripening of positive, negative, or neutral karmic imprints in our mind.</p>
<p id="Kashyapa"><strong>Kashyapa</strong> Buddha Kashyapa was the third Buddha to appear in this world and turn the Wheel of Dharma, the previous two being Buddha Krakuchchanda and Buddha Kanakamuni. Buddha Shakyamuni was the fourth, and Buddha Maitreya will be the fifth.</p>
<p id="Keajra"><strong>Keajra</strong> Sanskrit word for <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Dakini-Land">Dakini Land</a>, the Pure Land of Buddha Vajrayogini and Buddha Heruka. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/essence-of-vajrayana">Essence of Vajrayana</a>.</p>
<p id="228;drubje" class="#Kh&amp;"><strong>Khädrubje (AD 1385-1438)</strong> One of the principal disciples of Je Tsongkhapa, who did much to promote the tradition of Je Tsongkhapa after he passed away. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Khandarohi"><strong>Khandarohi</strong> One of the eight Goddesses of the body wheel of the Heruka mandala. Her main function is to dispel the obstacles of practitioners. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Khatanga"><strong>Khatanga</strong> A ritual object symbolizing the sixty-two Deities of Heruka.</p>
<p id="Kusali"><strong>Kusali</strong> Literally, `Possessor of Virtue’. A name given to great meditators who practise secretly while outwardly appearing as ordinary people. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Lama"><strong>Lama</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Spiritual-Guide">Spiritual Guide</a>.</p>
<p id="Lama-Losang-Tubwang-Dorjechang"><strong>Lama Losang Tubwang Dorjechang</strong> A special manifestation of Je Tsongkhapa revealed directly to the great Yogi Dharmavajra. In this manifestation, Je Tsongkhapa appears as a fully ordained monk wearing a long-eared Pandit’s hat, with Buddha Shakyamuni at his heart, and Conqueror Vajradhara at his heart. In the practice of Offering to the Spiritual Guide, we visualize our Spiritual Guide in this aspect. `Lama’ indicates that he is our Spiritual Guide, `Losang’ that he is Je Tsongkhapa (whose ordained name was Losang Dragpa), `Tubwang’ that he is Buddha Shakyamuni, and `Dorjechang’ that he is Vajradhara. In Tibetan, this aspect of our Spiritual Guide is also known as `je sempa sum tseg’, which means `Je Tsongkhapa, the Unification of Three Holy Beings’. This indicates that in reality our Spiritual Guide is the same nature as Je Tsongkhapa, Buddha Shakyamuni, and Conqueror Vajradhara. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Lamrim"><strong>Lamrim</strong> A Tibetan term, literally meaning `stages of the path’. A special arrangement of all Buddha’s teachings that is easy to understand and put into practice. It reveals all the stages of the path to enlightenment. For a full commentary, see <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Land-of-the-Thirty-three Heavens"><strong>Land of the Thirty-three Heavens</strong> One of the six abodes of desire realm gods. These are, in sequence: Land of the Four Great Kings, Land of the Thirty-three Heavens, Land Without Combat, Joyful Land, Land of Enjoying Emanations, and Land of Controlling Emanations.</p>
<p id="Langri-Tangpa"><strong>Langri Tangpa, Geshe (AD 1054-1123)</strong> A great Kadampa Teacher who was famous for his realization of exchanging self with others. He composed Eight Verses of Training the Mind. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/eight-steps-to-happiness">Eight Steps to Happiness</a>.</p>
<p id="Laziness"><strong>Laziness</strong> A deluded mental factor that, motivated by attachment to worldly pleasures or worldly activities, dislikes virtuous activity. There are three types of laziness: laziness arising from attachment to worldly pleasures, laziness arising from attachment to distracting activities, and laziness arising from discouragement. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Learner-Superiors"><strong>Learner Superiors</strong> Superior beings who are still training on the learning paths; that is, Superior beings on either the path of seeing or the path of meditation.</p>
<p id="Letter"><strong>Letter</strong> A vocalization that is a basis for the composition of names and phrases. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Liberation"><strong>Liberation</strong> ‘Nirvana’ in Sanskrit. Complete freedom from samsara and its cause, the delusions. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Life-supporting-wind"><strong>Life-supporting wind</strong> An inner energy wind that resides in the heart chakra, and functions to maintain the connection between our mind and body. When its strength diminishes, the connection is broken, and we die. This wind has three levels: gross, subtle, and very subtle. It is the very subtle wind that travels from life to life, supporting the very subtle mind. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/living-meaningfully-dying-joyfully">Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>.</p>
<p id="Lineage"><strong>Lineage</strong> A line of instruction that has been passed down from Spiritual Guide to disciple, with each Spiritual Guide in the line having gained personal experience of the instruction before passing it on to others.</p>
<p id="Lineage-Gurus"><strong>Lineage Gurus</strong> The line of Spiritual Guides through whom a particular instruction has been passed down.</p>
<p id="Ling-Rinpoche"><strong>Ling Rinpoche (AD 1903-1983)</strong> The Senior Tutor of the 14th Dalai Lama.</p>
<p id="Living-being"><strong>Living being</strong> Synonymous with sentient being (Tib. sem chän). Any being who possesses a mind that is contaminated by delusions or their imprints. Both `living being’ and `sentient being’ are terms used to distinguish beings whose minds are contaminated by either of these two obstructions from Buddhas, whose minds are completely free from these obstructions.</p>
<p id="Lochana"><strong>Lochana</strong> A female Buddha who is the manifestation of the earth element of all Buddhas.</p>
<p id="Lojong"><strong>Lojong</strong> A Tibetan term, literally meaning `training the mind’. A special lineage of instructions that came from Buddha Shakyamuni through Manjushri and Shantideva to Atisha and the Kadampa Geshes, which emphasizes the generation of bodhichitta through the practices of equalizing and exchanging self with others combined with taking and giving. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/universal-compassion">Universal Compassion</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/eight-steps-to-happiness">Eight Steps to Happiness</a>.</p>
<p id="Long-life-god"><strong>Long-life god</strong> An inhabitant of Great Result, one of the fourth form realms. Long-life gods are explained in the Lamrim teachings on the eight unfree states. They experience only two gross minds – one when they realize that they have taken heavenly rebirth and the other when they are about to die. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Lord-of-Death"><strong>Lord of Death</strong> Although the mara of uncontrolled death is not a sentient being, it is personified as the Lord of Death, or ‘Yama’. The Lord of Death is depicted in the diagram of the Wheel of Life clutching the wheel between his claws and teeth. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> .</p>
<p id="Lorig"><strong>Lorig</strong> Tibetan term for `types of mind’.</p>
<p id="Losang Dragpa"><strong>Losang Dragpa</strong> ‘Sumati Kirti’ in Sanskrit. The ordained name of Je Tsongkhapa. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Lotus posture"><strong>Lotus posture</strong> A sitting posture where the soles of both feet are pressed together.</p>
<p id="Love"><strong>Love</strong> A mind wishing others to be happy. There are three types: affectionate love, cherishing love, and wishing love. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/eight-steps-to-happiness">Eight Steps to Happiness</a>.</p>
<p id="Lower-realms"><strong>Lower realms</strong> The hell realm, hungry spirit realm, and animal realm. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Samsara">Samsara</a>.</p>
<p id="Madhyamika"><strong>Madhyamika</strong> A Sanskrit term, literally meaning ‘Middle Way’. The higher of the two schools of Mahayana tenets. The Madhyamika view was taught by Buddha in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras during the second turning of the Wheel of Dharma and was subsequently elucidated by Nagarjuna and his followers. There are two divisions of this school, Madhyamika-Svatantrika and Madhyamika-Prasangika, of which the latter is Buddha’s final view. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Mahakala"><strong>Mahakala</strong> A Dharma Protector who appears in many different aspects – four-armed, six-armed, four-faced, and so forth.</p>
<p id="Mahakaruna"><strong>Mahakaruna</strong> Sanskrit term for `great compassion’, and also an epithet for Buddha Avalokiteshvara.</p>
<p id="Mahamudra"><strong>Mahamudra</strong> A Sanskrit term, literally meaning `great seal’. According to Sutra, this refers to the profound view of emptiness. Since emptiness is the nature of all phenomena, it is called a `seal’, and since a direct realization of emptiness enables us to accomplish the great purpose – complete liberation from the sufferings of samsara – it is also called `great’. According to Tantra, or Vajrayana, great seal is the union of spontaneous great bliss and emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/mahamudra-tantra">Mahamudra Tantra</a>.</p>
<p id="Mahasiddha"><strong>Mahasiddha</strong> Sanskrit term for `Greatly Accomplished One’, which is used to refer to Yogis or Yoginis with high attainments.</p>
<p id="Mahayana"><strong>Mahayana</strong> Sanskrit term for `Great Vehicle’, the spiritual path to great enlightenment. The Mahayana goal is to attain Buddhahood for the benefit of all sentient beings by completely abandoning delusions and their imprints. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Mahayana-path"><strong>Mahayana path</strong> A clear realization in the mental continuum of a Bodhisattva or a Buddha. There are five Mahayana paths: the Mahayana path of accumulation, the Mahayana path of preparation, the Mahayana path of seeing, the Mahayana path of meditation, and the Mahayana Path of No More Learning. The first four are necessarily in the continuum of a Bodhisattva and the last is necessarily in the continuum of a Buddha. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Maitreya"><strong>Maitreya</strong> The embodiment of the loving kindness of all the Buddhas. At the time of Buddha Shakyamuni he manifested as a Bodhisattva disciple in order to show Buddha’s disciples how to be perfect Mahayana disciples. In the future, he will manifest as the fifth founding Buddha.</p>
<p id="Mala"><strong>Mala</strong> A rosary used to count recitations of prayers or mantras, usually with one hundred and eight beads. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Mamaki"><strong>Mamaki</strong> A female Buddha who is the manifestation of the water element of all Buddhas.</p>
<p id="Mandala"><strong>Mandala</strong> Usually the celestial mansion in which a Tantric Deity abides, or the environment or Deities of a Buddha’s Pure Land. Sometimes it is used to refer to the essence of an element, for example `wind mandala’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/essence-of-vajrayana">Essence of Vajrayana</a>.</p>
<p id="Mandala"><strong>Mandala</strong> offering An offering of the entire universe visualized as a Pure Land, with all its inhabitants as pure beings. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Manifest-object"><strong>Manifest object</strong> An object whose initial realization by a valid cognizer does not depend upon logical reasons. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Manjushri"><strong>Manjushri</strong> The embodiment of the wisdom of all the Buddhas. At the time of Buddha Shakyamuni he manifested as a Bodhisattva disciple in order to show Buddha’s disciples how to be perfect Mahayana disciples. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>.</p>
<p id="Mantra"><strong>Mantra</strong> A Sanskrit word, literally meaning `mind protection’. Mantra protects the mind from ordinary appearances and conceptions. There are four types of mantra: mantras that are mind, mantras that are inner wind, mantras that are sound, and mantras that are form. In general, there are three types of mantra recitation: verbal recitation, mental recitation, and vajra recitation. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Mara"><strong>Mara</strong> ‘Mara’ is Sanskrit for ‘demon’, and refers to anything that obstructs the attainment of liberation or enlightenment. There are four principal types of mara: the mara of the delusions, the mara of contaminated aggregates, the mara of uncontrolled death, and the Devaputra maras. Of these, only the last are actual sentient beings. The principal Devaputra mara is wrathful Ishvara, the highest of the desire realm gods, who inhabits Land of Controlling Emanations. A Buddha is called a `Conqueror’ because he or she has conquered all four types of mara. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Marpa"><strong>Marpa (1012-1096)</strong> Marpa Lotsawa, or Marpa the translator, was a great lay Tantric Yogi and the Spiritual Guide of Milrepa. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Meaning-clear-light"><strong>Meaning clear light</strong> A mind of clear light that realizes emptiness directly without a generic image. Synonymous with inner Dakini Land. See Clear Light of Bliss.</p>
<p id="Medicine Buddha"><strong>Medicine Buddha</strong> Buddha’s Truth Body appears in the form of Medicine Buddha, with a blue-coloured body, one face and two hands, holding a jewelled bowl and a medicinal plant. His function is to release living beings from outer and inner sickness by bestowing blessings upon them.</p>
<p id="Meditation"><strong>Meditation</strong> Meditation is a mind that concentrates on a virtuous object, and is a mental action that is the main cause of mental peace. There are two types of meditation – analytical meditation and placement meditation. When we use our imagination, mindfulness, and powers of reasoning to find our object of meditation, this is analytical meditation. When we find our object and hold it single-pointedly, this is placement meditation. There are different types of object. Some, such as impermanence or emptiness, are objects apprehended by the mind. Others, such as love, compassion, and renunciation, are actual states of mind. We engage in analytical meditation until the specific object that we seek appears clearly to our mind or until the particular state of mind that we wish to generate arises. This object or state of mind is our object of placement meditation. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Analytical-meditation">Analytical meditation</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Placement-meditation">Placement meditation</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-new-meditation-handbook">The New Meditation Handbook</a>.</p>
<p id="Meditation-break"><strong>Meditation break</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Subsequent-attainment">Subsequent attainment</a>.</p>
<p id="Meditative-equipoise"><strong>Meditative equipoise</strong> Single-pointed concentration on a virtuous object such as emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Mental-awareness"><strong>Mental awareness</strong> All minds are included within the five sense awarenesses and mental awareness. Mental awareness is an awareness that is developed in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a mental power. There are two types of mental awareness: conceptual mental awareness and non-conceptual mental awareness. Conceptual mental awareness and conceptual mind are synonyms. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Mental-continuum"><strong>Mental continuum</strong> The continuum of a person’s mind that has no beginning and no end.</p>
<p id="Mental-direct-perceiver"><strong>Mental direct perceiver</strong> A direct perceiver that is generated in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a mental power. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Mental-excitement"><strong>Mental excitement</strong> A deluded mental factor that wanders to any object of attachment. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Mental-factor "><strong>Mental factor</strong> A cognizer that principally apprehends a particular attribute of an object. There are fifty-one specific mental factors. Each moment of mind comprises a primary mind and various mental factors. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Mental-image"><strong>Mental image</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Generic-image">Generic image</a>.</p>
<p id="Mentality"><strong>Mentality</strong> Mentality, primary mind, and consciousness are synonyms.</p>
<p id="Mental-power"><strong>Mental power</strong> A mind that principally functions directly to produce the uncommon aspect of a mental awareness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Mental-sinking"><strong>Mental sinking</strong> A mental factor that destroys the clarity of concentration and its firm hold upon the object. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Mental-stabilization"><strong>Mental stabilization</strong> Generally, the terms ‘mental stabilization’ and ‘concentration’ are interchangeable. More specifically, the term ‘concentration’ is used to refer to the nature of concentration, which is single-pointedness, and the term ‘mental stabilization’ is used to refer to the function of concentration, which is stability. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Mental-suppleness"><strong>Mental suppleness</strong> A flexibility of mind induced by virtuous concentration. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Mere-appearance"><strong>Mere appearance</strong> All phenomena are mere appearance because they are imputed by mind in dependence upon a suitable basis of imputation appearing to mind. The word ‘mere’ excludes any possibility of inherent existence. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Merit"><strong>Merit</strong> The good fortune created by virtuous actions. It is the potential power to increase our good qualities and produce happiness.</p>
<p id="Middle-way"><strong>Middle way</strong> ‘Madhyamika’ in Sanskrit. The correct view of emptiness avoids both extremes and therefore emptiness is called the ‘middle way’. The higher of the two schools of Mahayana tenets. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Madhyamika">Madhyamika</a>.</p>
<p id="Migrator"><strong>Migrator</strong> A being within samsara who migrates from one uncontrolled rebirth to another.</p>
<p id="Migtsema"><strong>Migtsema</strong> A special prayer of praise and requests to Je Tsongkhapa composed by Manjushri in the Kadam Emanation Scripture. The prayer appears in various forms, such as the nine-line and five-line versions. This prayer is very blessed, and those who recite it with faith are able to accomplish great results. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>.</p>
<p id="Milarepa"><strong>Milarepa (1040-1123)</strong> A great Tibetan Buddhist meditator and disciple of Marpa, celebrated for his beautiful songs of realization.</p>
<p id="Mind"><strong>Mind</strong> That which is clarity and cognizes. Mind is clarity because it always lacks form and because it possesses the actual power to perceive objects. Mind cognizes because its function is to know or perceive objects. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/mahamudra-tantra">Mahamudra Tantra</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>.</p>
<p id="Mind-of-enlightenment"><strong>Mind of enlightenment</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Bodhichitta">Bodhichitta</a>.</p>
<p id="Mindfulness"><strong>Mindfulness</strong> A mental factor that functions not to forget the object realized by the primary mind. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>.</p>
<p id="Miracle-powers"><strong>Miracle powers</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Clairvoyance">Clairvoyance</a>.</p>
<p id="Miserliness"><strong>Miserliness</strong> A deluded mental factor that, motivated by desirous attachment, holds onto things tightly and does not want to part with them. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Mistaken-appearance"><strong>Mistaken appearance</strong> All minds of sentient beings, except for the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of a Superior being observing emptiness, are mistaken awarenesses because their objects appear to be truly existent; and this appearance is a mistaken appearance that is by nature an obstruction to omniscience. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Mistaken-awareness/mind"><strong>Mistaken awareness/mind</strong> A mind that is mistaken with respect to its appearing object. Although all minds of ordinary beings are mistaken, they are not necessarily wrong. A wrong mind is a mind that is mistaken with respect to its engaged object. Thus our eye awareness perceiving this page is a mistaken mind because the page appears as inherently existent, but it is a correct mind because it correctly apprehends the page as a page. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Moral-discipline"><strong>Moral discipline</strong> A virtuous mental determination to abandon any fault, or a bodily or verbal action motivated by such a determination. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Mother-Tantra"><strong>Mother Tantra</strong> A Tantra that principally reveals methods for attaining clear light.</p>
<p id="Mount-Meru"><strong>Mount Meru</strong> According to Buddhist cosmology, a divine mountain that stands at the centre of the universe. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Mudra"><strong>Mudra</strong> Generally, the Sanskrit word for `seal’, as in `Mahamudra’, the `great seal’. More specifically, `mudra’ is used to refer to a consort, as in `action mudra’ or `wisdom mudra’; and to hand gestures used in Tantric rituals.</p>
<p id="Mundane-happiness"><strong>Mundane happiness</strong> The limited happiness that can be found within samsara, such as the happiness of humans and gods.</p>
<p id="Mundane-paths"><strong>Mundane paths</strong> Contaminated actions that lead to samsaric rebirth. There are two types: the ten non-virtuous actions that lead to the lower realms, and the ten virtuous actions and contaminated concentrations that lead to the higher realms.</p>
<p id="Nada"><strong>Nada</strong> A three-curved line that appears above certain seed-letters.</p>
<p id="Naga"><strong>Naga</strong> A non-human being not normally visible to human beings. Their upper half is said to be human, their lower half serpent. Nagas usually live in the oceans of the world but they sometimes inhabit land in the region of rocks and trees. They are very powerful, some being benevolent and some malevolent. Many diseases, known as `naga diseases’, are caused by nagas and can only be cured through performing certain naga rituals.</p>
<p id="Nagarjuna"><strong>Nagarjuna</strong> A great Indian Buddhist scholar and meditation master who revived the Mahayana in the first century AD by bringing to light the teachings on the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras. Nagarjuna’s extraordinary life and works were prophesied by Buddha Shakyamuni. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Nalanda-Monastery"><strong>Nalanda Monastery</strong> A great seat of Buddhist learning and practice in ancient India.</p>
<p id="Name"><strong>Name</strong> An object of hearing that principally expresses the name of any phenomenon. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Namo"><strong>Namo</strong> A Sanskrit word of homage and respect.</p>
<p id="Naropa "><strong>Naropa (AD 1016-1100)</strong> An Indian Mahasiddha and a lineage Guru in the Highest Yoga Tantra practice of Vajrayogini. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Nature-Body"><strong>Nature Body</strong> The ultimate nature of a Buddha’s mind. Also known as `Entity Body’. See also Truth Body. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Negated-object"><strong>Negated object</strong> An object explicitly negated by a mind realizing a negative phenomenon. In meditation on emptiness, or lack of inherent existence, it refers to inherent existence. Also known as <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#object-of-negation">object of negation</a>.</p>
<p id="Negative-phenomenon"><strong>Negative phenomenon</strong> An object that is realized through the mind explicitly eliminating a negated object. There are two types of negative phenomenon: affirming negatives and non-affirming negatives. An affirming negative is a negative phenomenon realized by a mind that eliminates its negated object while realizing another phenomenon. A non-affirming negative is a negative phenomenon realized by a mind that merely eliminates its negated object without realizing another phenomenon. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Never-Returner"><strong>Never Returner</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Hearer">Hearer</a>.</p>
<p id="New-Kadampa-Tradition"><strong>New Kadampa Tradition (<span class="caps">NKT</span>)</strong> The union of Kadampa Buddhist Centres, an international association of study and meditation centres that follow the pure tradition of Mahayana Buddhism derived from the Buddhist meditator and scholar Je Tsongkhapa, introduced into the West by the Buddhist teacher Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso.</p>
<p id="Nine-mental-abidings"><strong>Nine mental abidings</strong> Nine levels of concentration leading to tranquil abiding: placing the mind, continual placement, replacement, close placement, controlling, pacifying, completely pacifying, single-pointedness, and placement in equipoise. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Nirvana"><strong>Nirvana</strong> Sanskrit word for ‘liberation’. Complete freedom from samsara and its cause, the delusions. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Nominal-truth"><strong>Nominal truth</strong> The objects we know simply by using their names without the need for analysis, such as our self, our body, and other things that we use in our everyday life. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-affirming-negative"><strong>Non-affirming negative</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Negative-phenomenon">Negative phenomenon</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-alertness"><strong>Non-alertness</strong> A deluded mental factor that, being unable to distinguish faults from non-faults, causes us to develop faults. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-ascertaining-perceiver"><strong>Non-ascertaining perceiver</strong> A cognizer to which a phenomenon that is its engaged object appears clearly without being ascertained. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-associated-compounded-phenomenon"><strong>Non-associated compounded phenomenon</strong> Any impermanent phenomenon that is neither form nor mind, such as person, life, time, and potentiality.</p>
<p id="Non-attachment"><strong>Non-attachment</strong> A mental factor that functions as the direct opponent of attachment. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/universal-compassion">Universal Compassion</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-conceptual-mind"><strong>Non-conceptual mind</strong> A cognizer to which its object appears clearly without being mixed with a generic image. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-conscientiousness"><strong>Non-conscientiousness</strong> A deluded mental factor that wishes to engage in non-virtuous actions without restraint. See “Understanding the Mind.</p>
<p id="Non-existent"><strong>Non-existent</strong> Traditional examples of non-existents are a horn on a rabbit’s head and a child of a barren woman. A horn on a rabbit’s head, for example, is not established by any valid mind and is consequently a non-existent rather than a conventional (or ultimate) truth. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-fabricated-bodhichitta"><strong>Non-fabricated bodhichitta</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Spontaneous-bodhichitta">Spontaneous bodhichitta</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-faith "><strong>Non-faith</strong> A deluded mental factor that is the opposite of faith. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-harmfulness"><strong>Non-harmfulness</strong> A mental factor that wishes sentient beings not to suffer. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-hatred"><strong>Non-hatred</strong> A mental factor that functions as the direct opponent of hatred. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/universal-compassion">Universal Compassion</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-ignorance"><strong>Non-ignorance</strong> A mental factor that functions as the direct opponent of ignorance. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/universal-compassion">Universal Compassion</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-valid cognizer"><strong>Non-valid cognizer</strong> A cognizer that is deceptive with respect to its engaged object. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-virtue"><strong>Non-virtue</strong> A phenomenon that functions as a main cause of suffering. It can refer to non-virtuous minds, non-virtuous actions, non-virtuous imprints, or the ultimate non-virtue of samsara. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Non-virtuous actions"><strong>Non-virtuous actions</strong> Paths that lead to the lower realms. Non-virtuous actions are countless, but most of them are included within the ten: killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, divisive speech, hurtful speech, idle gossip, covetousness, malice, and holding wrong views. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="228;" class="#Nyungn&amp;"><strong>Nyungnä</strong> A fasting and purification retreat in conjunction with Eleven-faced Avalokiteshvara.</p>
<p id="Object-of-negation"><strong>Object of negation</strong> An object explicitly negated by a mind realizing a negative phenomenon. In meditation on emptiness, or lack of inherent existence, it refers to inherent existence. Also known as <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#negated-object">negated object</a>.</p>
<p id="Object-possessor"><strong>Object-possessor</strong> A functioning thing that expresses or cognizes an object. It includes expressive sounds, persons, and minds. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Object-to-be-abandoned"><strong>Object to be abandoned</strong> Any object that is the principal cause of suffering, such as ignorance, other delusions, or non-virtuous actions.</p>
<p id="Observed-object"><strong>Observed object</strong> Any object upon which the mind is focused. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Obstructions-to-liberation"><strong>Obstructions to liberation</strong> Obstructions that prevent the attainment of liberation. All delusions, such as ignorance, attachment, and anger, together with their seeds, are obstructions to liberation. Also called <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Delusion-obstructions">delusion-obstructions</a>.</p>
<p id="Obstructions-to-omniscience"><strong>Obstructions to omniscience</strong> The imprints of delusions, which prevent simultaneous and direct realization of all phenomena. Only Buddhas have overcome these obstructions.</p>
<p id="Offering"><strong>Offering</strong> That which delights the holy beings.</p>
<p id="Offering-to-the-Spiritual-Guide "><strong>Offering to the Spiritual Guide</strong> Lama Chöpa in Tibetan. A special Guru yoga of Je Tsongkhapa, in which our Spiritual Guide is visualized in the aspect of Lama Losang Tubwang Dorjechang. The instruction for this practice was revealed by Buddha Manjushri in the Kadam Emanation Scripture and written down by the first Panchen Lama (AD 1569-1662). It is an essential preliminary practice for Vajrayana Mahamudra. See also Lama Losang Tubwang Dorjechang. For a full commentary, see <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Once-Returner"><strong>Once Returner</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Hearer">Hearer</a>.</p>
<p id="Opponent-powers"><strong>Opponent powers</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Four-opponent-powers">Four opponent powers</a>“.</p>
<p id="Oral-transmission"><strong>Oral transmission</strong> The granting of blessings through verbal instruction. Receiving these blessings is essential for gaining authentic realizations. All the root texts and their commentaries have been passed down in a pure, unbroken lineage from Teacher to disciple from the time of Buddha Shakyamuni down to the present day. It is customary at the end of a teaching for the Teacher to recite all the words of the text, just as he or she heard them from his or her own Teacher. A disciple is not considered to have received a teaching until he or she has heard all the words from the mouth of a qualified Spiritual Guide. A teaching that has been received in this way is completely pure, and it carries the blessing of all the lineage Gurus who transmitted the same teachings in the past.</p>
<p id="Ordinary-appearance-and-conception"><strong>Ordinary appearance and conception</strong> Ordinary appearance is any appearance that is due to an impure mind, and ordinary conception is any mind that conceives things as ordinary. According to Tantra, ordinary appearances are obstructions to omniscience and ordinary conceptions are obstructions to liberation. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/mahamudra-tantra">Mahamudra Tantra</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Ordinary-being"><strong>Ordinary being</strong> Anyone who has not realized emptiness directly.</p>
<p id="Ordinary-conception "><strong>Ordinary conception</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Ordinary-appearance-and-conception">Ordinary appearance and conception</a>.</p>
<p id="Outer-Dakini-Land"><strong>Outer Dakini Land</strong> The Pure Land of Vajrayogini. See</p>
<p id="Parshavajra"><strong>Parshavajra</strong> The emptiness of tangible objects appearing in the form of an offering goddess. see <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Path/Spiritual-path"><strong>Path/Spiritual path</strong> An exalted awareness conjoined with non-fabricated, or spontaneous, renunciation. Spiritual path, spiritual ground, spiritual vehicle, and exalted awareness are synonyms. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Ground/Spiritual">Ground/Spiritual ground</a> ground. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Patience"><strong>Patience</strong> A virtuous determination to forbear harm, suffering, or profound Dharma. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/how-to-solve-our-human-problems">How to Solve Our Human Problems</a>.</p>
<p id="Perfection-of-wisdom"><strong>Perfection of wisdom</strong> Any wisdom maintained by bodhichitta motivation. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Perfection-of-Wisdom-Sutras"><strong>Perfection of Wisdom Sutras</strong> Sutras of the second turning of the Wheel of Dharma, in which Buddha revealed his final view of the ultimate nature of all phenomena – emptiness of inherent existence. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Perfection-Vehicle"><strong>Perfection Vehicle</strong> The Mahayana Sutra Vehicle.</p>
<p id="Performance-Tantra"><strong>Performance Tantra</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Four-classes-of-Tantra">Four classes of Tantra</a>.</p>
<p id="Permanent-phenomenon"><strong>Permanent phenomenon</strong> Phenomena are either permanent or impermanent. A permanent phenomenon is a phenomenon that does not depend upon causes and that does not disintegrate moment by moment. It lacks the characteristics of production, abiding, and disintegration.</p>
<p id="Person"><strong>Person</strong> An I imputed in dependence upon any of the five aggregates. Person, being, self, and I are synonyms. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Phabongkha-Rinpoche"><strong>Phabongkha Rinpoche</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Je-Phabongkhapa">Je Phabongkhapa</a>.</p>
<p id="Phenomena-source"><strong>Phenomena source</strong> A phenomenon that appears only to mental awareness. This can include form that appears exclusively to mental awareness, such as a dream mountain that appears to a dream eye awareness, which is called ‘form that is a phenomena source’. Phenomena source is also the name given to Buddha Vajrayogini’s mandala, which is symbolic of the source of all phenomena, emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Phrase"><strong>Phrase</strong> An object of hearing that indicates a meaning by connecting a name with a predicate. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Physical-suppleness"><strong>Physical suppleness</strong> A light and flexible tactile object within our body that develops when meditation causes a pure wind to pervade the body.</p>
<p id="Placement-meditation"><strong>Placement meditation</strong> Single-pointed concentration on a virtuous object. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-new-meditation-handbook">The New Meditation Handbook</a>.</p>
<p id="Positive-phenomenon"><strong>Positive phenomenon</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Affirmative-phenomenon">Affirmative phenomenon</a>.</p>
<p id="Powa"><strong>Powa</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Transference-of-consciousness">Transference of consciousness</a>.</p>
<p id="Prasangika"><strong>Prasangika</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Madhyamika">Madhyamika</a>.</p>
<p id="Pratimoksha"><strong>Pratimoksha</strong> Sanskrit term for `personal liberation’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-bodhisattva-vow">The Bodhisattva Vow</a>.</p>
<p id="Pratimoksha-vow"><strong>Pratimoksha vow</strong> ‘Pratimoksha’ is the Sanskrit term for ‘personal liberation’, and so a Pratimoksha vow is a vow that is motivated mainly by the wish to attain personal liberation. There are eight types of Pratimoksha vow. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-bodhisattva-vow">The Bodhisattva Vow</a>.</p>
<p id="Preceptor"><strong>Preceptor</strong> A Spiritual Guide who give us vows or commitments to observe.</p>
<p id="Precious-human-life"><strong>Precious human life</strong> A life that has eight special freedoms and ten special endowments that make it an ideal opportunity for training the mind in all the stages of the path to enlightenment. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Preparatory-practices"><strong>Preparatory practices</strong> Practices that prepare the mind for successful meditation, such as purifying the mind, accumulating merit, and receiving blessings. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/buddhism/sadhanas">Essence of Good Fortune</a> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/eight-steps-to-happiness">Eight Steps to Happiness</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-new-meditation-handbook">The New Meditation Handbook</a>.</p>
<p id="Preliminary-guide"><strong>Preliminary guide</strong> Altogether there are nine preliminary guides, so called because by engaging in them we are guided to the actual spiritual paths of Tantra. The four main ones are: (1) the guide of going for refuge and generating bodhichitta, (2) the guide of meditation and recitation of Vajrasattva, (3) the guide of Guru yoga, and (4) the guide of making mandala offerings. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Pretension"><strong>Pretension</strong> A deluded mental factor that, motivated by attachment to wealth or reputation, wishes to pretend that we possess qualities that we do not possess. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Pride"><strong>Pride</strong> A deluded mental factor that, through considering and exaggerating one’s own good qualities or possessions, feels arrogant. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Primary-mind"><strong>Primary mind</strong> A cognizer that principally apprehends the mere entity of an object. Synonymous with consciousness. There are six primary minds: eye consciousness, ear consciousness, nose consciousness, tongue consciousness, body consciousness, and mental consciousness. Each moment of mind comprises a primary mind and various mental factors. A primary mind and its accompanying mental factors are the same entity but have different functions. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Profound path"><strong>Profound path</strong> The profound path includes all the wisdom practices that lead to a direct realization of emptiness and ultimately to the Truth Body of a Buddha. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Proponents-of-things"><strong>Proponents of things</strong> The Vaibhashika, Sautrantika, and Chittamatra Buddhist schools are known as ‘proponents of things’ because they assert that things are truly existent. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Prostration"><strong>Prostration</strong> An action of showing respect with body, speech, or mind. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-bodhisattva-vow">The Bodhisattva Vow</a>.</p>
<p id="Puja"><strong>Puja</strong> A ceremony in which offerings and other acts of devotion are performed in front of holy beings.</p>
<p id="Pure-Dakini-Land"><strong>Pure Dakini Land</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Dakini-Land">Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Pure-Land"><strong>Pure Land</strong> A pure environment in which there are no true sufferings. There are many Pure Lands. For example, Tushita is the Pure Land of Buddha Maitreya, Sukhavati is the Pure Land of Buddha Amitabha, and Keajra is the Pure Land of Buddha Vajrayogini and Buddha Heruka. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/living-meaningfully-dying-joyfully">Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully</a>.</p>
<p id="Purification"><strong>Purification</strong> Generally, any practice that leads to the attainment of a pure body, speech, or mind. More specifically, a practice for purifying negative karma by means of the four opponent powers. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-bodhisattva-vow">The Bodhisattva Vow</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/universal-compassion">Universal Compassion</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Rasavajra"><strong>Rasavajra</strong> The emptiness of taste appearing in the form of an offering goddess. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Ratnasambhava"><strong>Ratnasambhava</strong> The manifestation of the aggregate of feeling of all Buddhas. He has a yellow-coloured body.</p>
<p id="Realization"><strong>Realization</strong> A stable and non-mistaken experience of a virtuous object that directly protects us from suffering.</p>
<p id="Re-cognizer "><strong>Re-cognizer</strong> A cognizer that realizes what has already been realized through the force of a previous valid cognizer. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Refuge"><strong>Refuge</strong> Actual protection. To go for refuge to Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha means to have faith in these Three Jewels and to rely upon them for protection from all fears and suffering. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a></p>
<p id="Regret"><strong>Regret</strong> A mental factor that feels remorse for actions done in the past. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Rejoicing"><strong>Rejoicing</strong> A joyful mind, free of jealousy or pride, that takes delight in the virtuous actions of ourself or others. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Renunciation"><strong>Renunciation</strong> The wish to be released from samsara. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Resentment"><strong>Resentment</strong> A deluded mental factor that maintains the continuum of anger without forgetting it, and wishes to retaliate. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/how-to-solve-our-human-problems">How to Solve Our Human Problems</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Retreat"><strong>Retreat</strong> A period of time during which we impose various restrictions on our actions of body, speech, and mind so as to be able to concentrate more fully on a particular spiritual practice. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Close-retreat">Close retreat</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>.</p>
<p id="root-guru"><strong>Root Guru</strong> The principal Spiritual Guide from whom we have received the empowerments, instructions, and oral transmissions of our main practice. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>. Guide to the Middle Way a classic Mahayana Buddhist text composed by the great Indian Buddhist Yogi and scholar Chandrakirti, which provides a comprehensive explanation of the Madhyamika-Prasangika view of emptiness as taught in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras. For a translation and full commentary, see <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Root mind"><strong>Root mind</strong> The very subtle mind located at the centre of the heart channel wheel. It is known as the ‘root mind’ because all other minds arise from it and dissolve back into it. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/mahamudra-tantra">Mahamudra Tantra</a>.</p>
<p id="Rupavajra"><strong>Rupavajra</strong> The emptiness of form appearing in the form of an offering goddess. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>:, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Sadhana"><strong>Sadhana</strong> A ritual prayer that is the special method for attainment, usually associated with a Tantric Deity.</p>
<p id="Samantabhadra"><strong>Samantabhadra</strong> Sanskrit name for ‘All Good One’, a Bodhisattva renowned for his extensive offerings. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Samkhya"><strong>Samkhya</strong> A non-Buddhist school, the oldest of the Brahmaic schools. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Samsara"><strong>Samsara</strong> The cycle of uncontrolled death and rebirth, or the cycle of twelve dependent-related links. Sometimes known as ‘cyclic existence’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Or:-</strong></p>
<p id="Samsara"><strong>Samsara</strong> This can be understood in two ways – as uninterrupted rebirth without freedom or control, or as the aggregates of a being who has taken such a rebirth. Samsara, sometimes known as ‘cyclic existence’, is characterized by suffering and dissatisfaction. There are six realms of samsara. Listed in ascending order according to the type of karma that causes rebirth in them, they are the realms of the hell beings, hungry spirits, animals, human beings, demi-gods, and gods. The first three are lower realms or unhappy migrations, and the second three are higher realms or happy migrations. Although from the point of view of the karma that causes rebirth there, the god realm is the highest realm in samsara, the human realm is said to be the most fortunate realm because it provides the best conditions for attaining liberation and enlightenment. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Sangha"><strong>Sangha</strong> According to the Vinaya tradition, any community of four or more fully ordained monks or nuns. In general, ordained or lay people who take Bodhisattva vows or Tantric vows can also be said to be Sangha. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Sangha-Jewel"><strong>Sangha Jewel</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Three-Jewels">Three Jewels</a>.</p>
<p id="Sanskrit-vowels-and-consonants"><strong>Sanskrit vowels and consonants</strong> The source of the three letters <strong>OM AH <span class="caps">HUM</span></strong>, and of all mantras in general, is the sixteen Sanskrit vowels and the thirty-four Sanskrit consonants. The sixteen vowels are: <strong>A, AA, I, II, U, UU, RI, <span class="caps">RII</span>, LI, <span class="caps">LII</span>, E, AI, O, AU, AM, AH</strong>.
