The thirty-four consonants are: <strong>KA, <span class="caps">KHA</span>, GA, <span class="caps">GHA</span>, <span class="caps">NGA</span>, <span class="caps">CHA</span>, <span class="caps">CHHA</span>, JA, <span class="caps">JHA</span>, <span class="caps">NYA</span>, DA, <span class="caps">THA</span>, TA, <span class="caps">DHA</span>, NA, DrA, THrA, TrA, DHrA, NA, BA, <span class="caps">PHA</span>, PA, <span class="caps">BHA</span>, MA, YA, RA, LA, WA, <span class="caps">SHA</span>, KA, SA, HA, <span class="caps">KYA</span></strong>.</p>
<p id="Saraha"><strong>Saraha</strong> One of the first Mahasiddhas, and the Teacher of Nagarjuna. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/essence-of-vajrayana">Essence of Vajrayana</a>.</p>
<p id="Sautrantika"><strong>Sautrantika</strong> The higher of the two schools of Hinayana tenets. This school accepts both self-cognizers and external objects to be truly existent. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Schools-of-Buddhist-philosophy/tenets "><strong>Schools of Buddhist philosophy/tenets</strong> Four philosophical views taught by Buddha according to the inclinations and dispositions of disciples. They are the Vaibhashika, Sautrantika, Chittamatra, and Madhyamika schools. The first two are Hinayana schools and the second two are Mahayana schools. They are studied in sequence, the lower tenets being the means by which the higher ones are understood. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Secret-Mantra"><strong>Secret Mantra</strong> Synonymous with Tantra. Secret Mantra teachings are distinguished from Sutra teachings in that they reveal methods for training the mind by bringing the future result, or Buddhahood, into the present path. Secret Mantra is the supreme path to full enlightenment. The term `Mantra’ indicates that it is Buddha’s special instruction for protecting our mind from ordinary appearances and conceptions. Practitioners of Secret Mantra overcome ordinary appearances and conceptions by visualizing their body, environment, enjoyments, and deeds as those of a Buddha. The term `Secret’ indicates that the practices are to be done in private, and that they can be practised only by those who have received a Tantric empowerment. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Sectarianism"><strong>Sectarianism</strong> At the same time as cherishing our own tradition, we should respect all other traditions and the right of each individual to follow the tradition of their choosing. This approach leads to harmony and tolerance. It is mixing different religious traditions that causes sectarianism. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Seed-letter"><strong>Seed-letter</strong> The sacred letter from which a Deity is generated. Each Deity has a particular seed-letter. For example, the seed-letter of Manjushri is <span class="caps">DHI</span>, of Tara is <span class="caps">TAM</span>, of Vajrayogini is <span class="caps">BAM</span>, and of Heruka is <span class="caps">HUM</span>. To accomplish Tantric realizations, we need to recognize that Deities and their seed-letters are the same nature.</p>
<p id="Seed of delusion"><strong>Seed of delusion</strong> The seed of a delusion is the potentiality for that delusion to arise; it is the substantial cause of the delusion. Until we have finally abandoned a delusion, the seed of that delusion will remain within our mind, even when the delusion itself is not manifest. Seeds of delusions can be eradicated only by the wisdom directly realizing emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Segyu-Lineage"><strong>Segyu Lineage</strong> The lineage of the instructions on Ganden Lhagyäma, or The Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land, passed from Je Tsongkhapa to Je Sherab Senge, Paldän Sangpo, Khädrub Sangye Yeshe, and so on down to our present Teachers. This lineage is so called because the original Gurus came from a region of Tibet called Se. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Hundreds-of-Deities-of-the-Joyful-Land">Hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>.</p>
<p id="Self-cherishing"><strong>Self-cherishing</strong> A mental attitude that considers oneself to be supremely important and precious. It is regarded as a principal object to be abandoned by Bodhisattvas. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/eight-steps-to-happiness">Eight Steps to Happiness</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Self-cognizer"><strong>Self-cognizer</strong> A consciousness that experiences itself. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Self-grasping "><strong>Self-grasping</strong> A conceptual mind that holds any phenomenon to be inherently existent. The mind of self-grasping gives rise to all other delusions, such as anger and attachment. It is the root cause of all suffering and dissatisfaction. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Selflessness"><strong>Selflessness</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/en/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Emptiness">Emptiness</a>.</p>
<p id="Self-satisfaction"><strong>Self-satisfaction</strong> A deluded mental factor that observes our own physical beauty, wealth, or other good qualities, and being concerned only with these, has no interest in spiritual development. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Sense-awareness"><strong>Sense awareness</strong> All minds are included within sense awareness and mental awareness. The definition of sense awareness is an awareness that is developed in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a sense power possessing form. There are five types of sense awareness: eye awareness, ear awareness, nose awareness, tongue awareness, and body awareness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Sense-direct-perceiver"><strong>Sense direct perceiver</strong> A direct perceiver that is generated in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a sense power possessing form. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Sense-of-shame"><strong>Sense of shame</strong> A mental factor that functions to avoid inappropriate actions for reasons that concern oneself. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Sense power"><strong>Sense power</strong> An inner power located in the very centre of a sense organ that functions directly to produce a sense awareness. There are five sense powers, one for each type of sense awareness – the eye awareness and so forth. They are sometimes known as `sense powers possessing form’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Sentient-being"><strong>Sentient being</strong> ‘Sem chän’ in Tibetan. Any being who possesses a mind that is contaminated by delusions or their imprints. Both `sentient being’ and `living being’ are terms used to distinguish beings whose minds are contaminated by either of these two obstructions from Buddhas, whose minds are completely free from these obstructions.</p>
<p id="Seven-limbs"><strong>Seven limbs</strong> Special practices for purifying negativity and accumulating merit. They are prostration, offering, confession, rejoicing, beseeching the holy beings not to pass away, requesting the turning of the Wheel of Dharma, and dedication. They are called `limbs’ because they provide support for the main body of our practice, which is the actual meditations on the paths of Sutra and Tantra. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Sevenfold-cause-and-effect"><strong>Sevenfold cause and effect</strong> A method for generating bodhichitta in which affectionate love is developed primarily by recognizing all sentient beings as our mothers and remembering their kindness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Seven-point-posture-of-Vairochana"><strong>Seven-point posture of Vairochana</strong> A special posture for meditation, in which parts of our body adopt a particular position: (1) sitting on a comfortable cushion with the legs crossed in the vajra posture (in which the feet are placed upon the opposite thighs), (2) the back straight, (3) the head inclined slightly forward, (4) the eyes remaining open slightly, gazing down the nose, (5) the shoulders level, (6) the mouth gently closed, and (7) the right hand placed upon the left, palms up, four finger widths below the navel with the two thumbs touching just above the navel.</p>
<p id="Shakyamuni"><strong>Shakyamuni</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/en/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Buddha-Shakyamuni">Buddha Shakyamuni</a>.</p>
<p id="Shamelessness"><strong>Shamelessness</strong> A deluded mental factor that is the opposite of sense of shame. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Shantideva"><strong>Shantideva (AD 687-763)</strong> A great Indian Buddhist scholar and meditation master. He composed <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-the-bodhisattvas-way-of-life">Guide to the Bodhisattva’s Way of Life</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Shaptavajra"><strong>Shaptavajra</strong> The emptiness of sound appearing in the form of an offering goddess. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Shariputra"><strong>Shariputra</strong> One of Buddha Shakyamuni’s principal disciples. He has the aspect of a Hinayana Foe Destroyer. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Siddhi"><strong>Siddhi</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/en/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Attainment">Attainment</a>.</p>
<p id="Sindhura"><strong>Sindhura</strong> A red powder from any of the Twenty-four Auspicious Places of Heruka. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Six-perfections"><strong>Six perfections</strong> The perfections of giving, moral discipline, patience, effort, mental stabilization, and wisdom. They are called `perfections’ because they are motivated by bodhichitta. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Six powers"><strong>Six powers</strong> The five sense powers and the mental power. A sense power is an inner power located in the very centre of a sense organ that functions directly to produce a sense awareness. There are five sense powers, one for each type of sense awareness. A mental power is a mind that principally functions directly to produce the uncommon aspect of a mental awareness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Six-realms "><strong>Six realms</strong> There are six realms of samsara. Listed in ascending order according to the type of karma that causes rebirth in them, they are the realms of the hell beings, hungry spirits, animals, human beings, demi-gods, and gods. The first three are lower realms or unhappy migrations, and the second three are higher realms or happy migrations. Although from the point of view of the karma that causes rebirth there, the god realm is the highest realm in samsara, the human realm is said to be the most fortunate realm because it provides the best conditions for attaining liberation and enlightenment. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Sixteen-characteristics-of-the-four-noble-truths"><strong>Sixteen characteristics of the four noble truths</strong> Buddha taught that each of the four noble truths has four special characteristics. The four characteristics of true sufferings are: impermanent, suffering, empty, and selfless. The four characteristics of true origins are: cause, origin, strong producer, and condition. The four characteristics of true cessations are: cessation, peace, supreme attainment, and definite abandoner. The four characteristics of true paths are: path, antidote, accomplisher, and definite abandoning. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Sixty-two-Deities"><strong>Sixty-two Deities of Heruka</strong> There are sixty-two Deities in Heruka’s mandala: six Deities of the great bliss wheel, sixteen Deities of the heart wheel, sixteen Deities of the speech wheel, sixteen Deities of the body wheel, and eight Deities of the commitment wheel. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Sleep"><strong>Sleep</strong> A mental factor that is developed through dullness or its imprints and that functions to gather the sense awarenesses inwards. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Solitary-peace"><strong>Solitary peace</strong> A Hinayana nirvana.</p>
<p id="Solitary-Realizer"><strong>Solitary Realizer</strong> One of two types of Hinayana practitioner. Also known as `Solitary Conqueror’. Both Hearers and Solitary Realizers are Hinayanists, but they differ in their motivation, behaviour, merit, and wisdom. In all these respects, Solitary Realizers are superior to Hearers. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Spiritual-Guide"><strong>Spiritual Guide</strong> ‘Guru’ in Sanskrit, ‘Lama’ in Tibetan. A Teacher who guides us along the spiritual path. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Spite"><strong>Spite</strong> A deluded mental factor that, motivated by resentment or aggression, wishes to speak harshly. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Spontaneous-bodhichitta-Actual-bodhichitta"><strong>Spontaneous bodhichitta Actual bodhichitta</strong> Also known as `non-fabricated bodhichitta’, this mind arises spontaneously day and night. At first we generate an artificial, or fabricated, bodhichitta at certain times by contemplating the suffering of others and so forth, and this acts as the foundation for developing actual bodhichitta.</p>
<p id="Spontaneous-great-bliss"><strong>Spontaneous great bliss</strong> A special bliss that is produced by the drops melting inside the central channel. It is attained by gaining control over the inner winds. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Stages-of-the-path"><strong>Stages of the path</strong> ‘Lamrim’ in Tibetan. A special arrangement of all Buddha’s teachings that is easy to understand and put into practice. It reveals all the stages of the path to enlightenment. For a full commentary, see <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Stream Enterer"><strong>Stream Enterer</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Hearer">Hearer</a>.</p>
<p id="Stupa"><strong>Stupa</strong> A symbolic representation of Buddha’s mind.</p>
<p id="Subsequent-attainment"><strong>Subsequent attainment</strong> The period between meditation sessions. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Substantial-cause"><strong>Substantial cause</strong> Main cause.</p>
<p id="Subtle impermanence"><strong>Subtle impermanence</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Impermanent-phenomenon">Impermanent phenomenon</a>.</p>
<p id="Sugata"><strong>Sugata</strong> Another Sanskrit term for a Buddha. It indicates that Buddhas have attained a state of immaculate and indestructible bliss.</p>
<p id="Sukhavati"><strong>Sukhavati</strong> Sanskrit term for ‘Pure Land of Bliss’ or ‘Blissful Land’ – the Pure Land of Buddha Amitabha.</p>
<p id="Superior-being"><strong>Superior being</strong> ‘Arya’ in Sanskrit. A being who has a direct realization of emptiness. There are Hinayana Superiors and Mahayana Superiors.</p>
<p id="Superior-intention"><strong>Superior intention</strong> Motivated by great compassion, the determination to take personal responsibility to release others from suffering and lead them to perfect happiness. See Joyful Path of Good Fortune.</p>
<p id="Superior-seeing"><strong>Superior seeing</strong> A special wisdom that sees its object clearly, and that is maintained by tranquil abiding and the special suppleness that is induced by investigation. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Suppleness"><strong>Suppleness</strong> There are two types of suppleness, mental and physical. Mental suppleness is a flexibility of mind induced by virtuous concentration. Physical suppleness is a light and flexible tactile object within our body that develops when meditation causes a pure wind to pervade the body.</p>
<p id="Supramundane-happiness"><strong>Supramundane happiness</strong> The pure happiness of liberation and enlightenment.</p>
<p id="Supramundane path"><strong>Supramundane path</strong> Any path leading to liberation or enlightenment – for example, the realizations of renunciation, bodhichitta, and the correct view of emptiness. Strictly speaking, only Superior beings possess supramundane paths. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Supreme-attainments"><strong>Supreme attainments</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Attainment">Attainment</a>.</p>
<p id="Supreme-Emanation-Body"><strong>Supreme Emanation Body</strong> A special Emanation Body displaying the thirty-two major signs and eighty minor indications that can be seen by ordinary beings only if they have very pure karma. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Buddha&#39;s-bodies">Buddha’s bodies</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Emanation-Body">Emanation Body</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Or:-</strong></p>
<p id="Supreme-Emanation-Body"><strong>Supreme Emanation Body</strong> An Emanation Body who performs the twelve principal deeds, such as Buddha Shakyamuni, is called a ‘Supreme Emanation Body’. From the point of view of external aspect, such an emanation is supreme, but from the point of view of nature, all beings emanated by a Buddha, however mundane in aspect, are supreme beings. Therefore, we should not infer from the name ‘Supreme Emanation Body’ that there are higher and lower emanations of Buddha. In essence, all Buddha’s emanations are fully enlightened beings. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Buddha&#39;s-bodies">Buddha’s bodies</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>..</p>
<p id="Sutra"><strong>Sutra</strong> The teachings of Buddha that are open to everyone to practise without the need for empowerment. These include Buddha’s teachings of the three turnings of the Wheel of Dharma.</p>
<p id="Svatantrika"><strong>Svatantrika</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Madhyamika">Madhyamika</a>.</p>
<p id="Tangkha"><strong>Tangkha</strong> A traditional Buddhist painting of a holy being.</p>
<p id="Tangyur"><strong>Tängyur</strong> The collection of commentaries to Buddha’s teachings that have been translated from Sanskrit into Tibetan. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kangyur">Kangyur</a>.</p>
<p id="Tantra"><strong>Tantra</strong> Synonymous with Secret Mantra. Tantric teachings are distinguished from Sutra teachings in that they reveal methods for training the mind by bringing the future result, or Buddhahood, into the present path. Tantric practitioners overcome ordinary appearances and conceptions by visualizing their body, environment, enjoyments, and deeds as those of a Buddha. Tantra is the supreme path to full enlightenment. Tantric practices are to be done in private and only by those who have received a Tantric empowerment. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/mahamudra-tantra">Mahamudra Tantra</a>.</p>
<p id="Tantric-bodhichitta"><strong>Tantric bodhichitta</strong> A wish to attain enlightenment as a Tantric Deity in order to rescue sentient beings from samsara as quickly as possible. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a> .</p>
<p id="Tantric-Mahamudra"><strong>Tantric Mahamudra</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Mahamudra">Mahamudra</a>.</p>
<p id="Tara"><strong>Tara</strong> A female Buddha who is a manifestation of the ultimate wisdom of all the Buddhas. ‘Tara’ means ‘Rescuer’. Since she is a wisdom Buddha, and since she is a manifestation of the completely purified wind element, Tara is able to help us very quickly.</p>
<p id="Tathagata"><strong>Tathagata</strong> The Sanskrit for `A Being Gone Beyond’, which is another term for Buddha.</p>
<p id="Ten-directions"><strong>Ten directions</strong> The four cardinal directions, the four intermediate directions, and the directions above and below.</p>
<p id="Tenets"><strong>Tenets</strong> There are four schools of Buddhist tenets, which are four philosophical views taught by Buddha according to the inclinations and dispositions of disciples. They are the Vaibashika, Sautrantika, Chittamatra, and Madhyamika schools. The first two are Hinayana schools and the second two are Mahayana schools. They are studied in sequence, the lower tenets being the means by which the higher ones are understood. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Ten-perfections"><strong>Ten perfections</strong> The six perfections as well as the perfections of skilful means, prayer, force, and exalted awareness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Thing"><strong>Thing</strong> A phenomenon that is produced and disintegrates within a moment. Synonymous with impermanent phenomenon, functioning thing, and product. (or, sometimes, just say “See Functioning thing.”)</p>
<p id="Thirty-five-Confession-Buddhas"><strong>Thirty-five Confession Buddhas</strong> Thirty-five Buddhas who have special powers to purify negativities and downfalls in those who recite their names with faith. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-bodhisattva-vow">The Bodhisattva Vow</a>.</p>
<p id="Thirty-seven-realizations-conducive-to-enlightenment"><strong>Thirty-seven realizations conducive to enlightenment</strong> Any spiritual path that leads to enlightenment. There are seven groups: four close placements of mindfulness, four correct abandoners, four legs of miracle powers, five powers, five forces, seven branches of enlightenment, and eight branches of superior paths. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Thirty-two-major-signs"><strong>Thirty-two major signs</strong> Sometimes called the `major marks’. Special characteristics of a Buddha’s form. Examples are the sign of the wheel on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. The eighty indications, sometimes called the `minor marks’, include signs such as copper-coloured nails.</p>
<p id="Three-higher-trainings"><strong>Three higher trainings</strong> Training in moral discipline, concentration, and wisdom motivated by renunciation or bodhichitta.</p>
<p id="Three-Jewels"><strong>Three Jewels</strong> The three objects of refuge: Buddha Jewel, Dharma Jewel, and Sangha Jewel. They are called `Jewels’ because they are both rare and precious. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Three-principal-aspects-of-the-path"><strong>Three principal aspects of the path</strong> The realizations of renunciation, bodhichitta, and wisdom realizing emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Three-realms"><strong>Three realms</strong> The three levels within samsara: the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm. The desire realm is the environment of hell beings, hungry spirits, animals, human beings, demi-gods, and the gods who enjoy the five objects of desire. The form realm is the environment of the gods who possess form. The formless realm is the environment of the gods who do not possess form. Beings of the desire realm have powerful delusions, beings of the form realm have more subtle delusions, and beings of the formless realm have very subtle delusions. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Desire-realm">Desire realm</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Form-realm">Form realm</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Formless-realm">Formless realm</a>.</p>
<p id="Three-times"><strong>Three times</strong> Past, present, and future. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Three-worlds"><strong>Three worlds</strong> The naga world beneath, the human world above, and the god world on high. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Torma-offering"><strong>Torma offering</strong> A special food offering made according to either Sutric or Tantric rituals. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/essence-of-vajrayana">Essence of Vajrayana</a>.</p>
<p id="Training-the-mind"><strong>Training the mind</strong> ‘Lojong’ in Tibetan. A special lineage of instructions that came from Buddha Shakyamuni through Manjushri and Shantideva to Atisha and the Kadampa Geshes, which emphasizes the generation of bodhichitta through the practices of equalizing and exchanging self with others combined with taking and giving. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/universal-compassion">Universal Compassion</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/eight-steps-to-happiness">Eight Steps to Happiness</a>.</p>
<p id="Training-the Mind-in-Seven-Points"><strong>Training the Mind in Seven Points</strong> A commentary to Eight Verses of Training the Mind, composed by Bodhisattva Chekhawa. For a full commentary, see <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/universal-compassion">Universal Compassion</a>.</p>
<p id="Tranquil-abiding"><strong>Tranquil abiding</strong> A concentration that possesses the special bliss of physical and mental suppleness that is attained in dependence upon completing the nine mental abidings. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a>.</p>
<p id="Transference-of-consciousness"><strong>Transference of consciousness</strong> ‘Powa’ in Tibetan. A practice for transferring the consciousness to a Pure Land at the time of death. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/living-meaningfully-dying-joyfully">Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Trijang-Rinpoche"><strong>Trijang Rinpoche (AD 1901-1981)</strong> A special Tibetan Lama of the twentieth century who was an emanation of Buddha Shakyamuni, Heruka, Atisha, Amitabha, and Je Tsongkhapa. Also known as `Trijang Dorjechang’ and `Losang Yeshe’.</p>
<p id="True-cessation"><strong>True cessation</strong> The ultimate nature of a mind freed from any obstruction by means of a true path. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="True-existence"><strong>True existence</strong> Existence in any way independent of conceptual imputation.</p>
<p id="True-grasping"><strong>True-grasping</strong> A conceptual mind that apprehends true existence.</p>
<p id="True-origin"><strong>True origin</strong> An action or a delusion that is the main cause of a true suffering. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="True-path"><strong>True path</strong> A spiritual path held by a wisdom directly realizing emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="True suffering"><strong>True suffering</strong> A contaminated object produced by delusions and karma. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Truth-Body"><strong>Truth Body</strong> ‘Dharmakaya’ in Sanskrit. The Wisdom Truth Body and the Nature Body of a Buddha. The first is Buddha’s omniscient mind, and the second is the emptiness, or ultimate nature, of his or her mind. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Tsog-offering"><strong>Tsog offering</strong> An offering made by an assembly of Heroes and Heroines. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/essence-of-vajrayana">Essence of Vajrayana</a>.</p>
<p id="Tsongkhapa"><strong>Tsongkhapa</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Je-Tsongkhapa">Je Tsongkhapa</a>.</p>
<p id="Tummo"><strong>Tummo</strong> Tibetan word for ‘inner fire’. An inner heat located at the centre of the navel channel wheel. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>.</p>
<p id="Tushita"><strong>Tushita</strong> ‘Joyful Land’ in English, ‘Ganden’ in Tibetan. The Pure Land of Buddha Maitreya. Both Je Tsongkhapa and Atisha went to this Pure Land after they passed away. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-jewel">Heart Jewel</a>.</p>
<p id="Twelve-dependent-links"><strong>Twelve dependent-related links</strong> Dependent-related ignorance, compositional actions, consciousness, name and form, six sources, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, existence, birth, and ageing and death. These twelve links are causes and effects that keep ordinary beings bound within samsara. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Twelve-principal-deeds"><strong>Twelve principal deeds</strong> The principal deeds of a Supreme Emanation Body: (1) descent from Joyful Land, (2) conception in a mother’s womb, (3) birth, (4) mastery of youthful skills and sports, (5) enjoyments with a wife and retinue, (6) ordination, (7) the practice of asceticism, (8) meditation under the Bodhi Tree, (9) overcoming the maras, (10) showing the attainment of enlightenment, (11) turning the Wheel of Dharma, (12) showing the manner of passing away. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Twelve-sources"><strong>Twelve sources</strong> The six powers (the eye sense power and so forth) and the six objects of those powers (visual forms and so forth). See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Twenty-four-holy-places"><strong>Twenty-four holy places</strong> Twenty-four special places in this world where the mandalas of Heruka and Vajrayogini still remain. They are: Puliramalaya, Dzalandhara, Odiyana, Arbuta, Godawari, Rameshöri, Dewikoti, Malawa, Kamarupa, Ote, Trishakune, Kosala, Kalinga, Lampaka, Kancha, Himalaya, Pretapuri, Grihadewata, Shauraktra, Suwanadvipa, Nagara, Sindhura, Maru, and Kuluta. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/essence-of-vajrayana">Essence of Vajrayana</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Two-collections"><strong>Two collections</strong> The collections of merit and wisdom. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Collection-of-merit">Collection of merit</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Collection-of-wisdom">#Collection of wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Two-extremes"><strong>Two extremes</strong> Buddha explains the middle way by refuting the two extremes: the extreme of existence (that phenomena are inherently existent) and the extreme of non-existence (that phenomena do not exist at all). See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Two-truths"><strong>Two truths</strong> Conventional truth and ultimate truth. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Two-obstructions"><strong>Two obstructions</strong> Obstructions to liberation and obstructions to omniscience. Hinayana Foe Destroyers and Bodhisattvas above the seventh ground have abandoned the obstructions to liberation but not the obstructions to omniscience. Consequently, when they are not in meditative equipoise on emptiness, objects appear to them as inherently existent. See also Obstructions to liberation and Obstructions to omniscience.</p>
<p id="Ultimate-bodhichitta"><strong>Ultimate bodhichitta</strong> A wisdom motivated by conventional bodhichitta that directly realizes emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/universal-compassion">Universal Compassion</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Ultimate-nature"><strong>Ultimate nature</strong> All phenomena have two natures – a conventional nature and an ultimate nature. In the case of a table, for example, the table itself, and its shape, colour, and so forth are all the conventional nature of the table. The ultimate nature of the table is the table’s lack of inherent existence. The conventional nature of a phenomenon is a conventional truth, and its ultimate nature is an ultimate truth. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Ultimate-truth"><strong>Ultimate truth</strong> The ultimate nature of all phenomena, emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/meaningful-to-behold">Meaningful to Behold</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Uncommon-Close-Lineage"><strong>Uncommon Close Lineage</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kadam-Emanation-Scripture">Kadam Emanation Scripture</a>.</p>
<p id="Uncommon-Whispered-Lineage"><strong>Uncommon Whispered Lineage</strong> of the Virtuous Tradition See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Kadam-Emanation-Scripture">Kadam Emanation Scripture</a>.</p>
<p id="Uncompounded-space"><strong>Uncompounded space</strong> Lack of obstructive contact. So called because it is not produced by causes and conditions and so is permanent. Also known as ‘unproduced space’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Uncontaminated-bliss"><strong>Uncontaminated bliss</strong> A realization of bliss conjoined with a wisdom directly realizing emptiness. See Guide to Dakini Land, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Union-of-No-More-Learning"><strong>Union of No More Learning</strong> A union of the pure illusory body and meaning clear light that has abandoned the obstructions to omniscience. Synonymous with Buddhahood. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Union-that-needs-learning"><strong>Union that needs learning</strong> A union of the pure illusory body and meaning clear light that has not yet abandoned the obstructions to omniscience. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Unobservable-compassion"><strong>Unobservable compassion</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Great-compassion">Great compassion</a>.</p>
<p id="Unproduced-space"><strong>Unproduced space</strong> Lack of obstructive contact. So called because it is not produced by causes and conditions and so is permanent. Also known as ‘uncompounded space’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Ushnisha"><strong>Ushnisha</strong> A Buddha’s crown protruberance. One of the thirty-two major signs.</p>
<p id="Vaibhashika"><strong>Vaibhashika</strong> The lower of the two schools of Hinayana tenets. This school does not accept self-cognizers and asserts external objects to be truly existent. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/en/books/meaningful-to-behold/">Meaningful to Behold</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Vairochana"><strong>Vairochana</strong> The manifestation of the aggregate of form of all Buddhas. He has a white-coloured body.</p>
<p id="Vajra"><strong>Vajra</strong> Generally, the Sanskrit word `vajra’ means indestructible like a diamond and powerful like a thunderbolt. In the context of Secret Mantra, it can mean the indivisibility of method and wisdom, omniscient great wisdom, or spontaneous great bliss. It is also the name given to a metal ritual object. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajra-and-bell"><strong>Vajra and bell</strong> A ritual sceptre symbolizing great bliss and a ritual hand-bell symbolizing emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajra-body"><strong>Vajra body</strong> Generally, the channels, drops, and inner winds. More specifically, the pure illusory body. The body of a Buddha is known as the `resultant vajra body’. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/clear-light-of-bliss">Clear Light of Bliss</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajra-brothers/sisters"><strong>Vajra brothers/sisters</strong> Practitioners who have received any Highest Yoga Tantra empowerment from the same Vajra Master, either at the same time or at different times. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajradaka-Burning-Offering"><strong>Vajradaka Burning Offering</strong> A special purification practice in which our negativities and downfalls are transformed into black sesame seeds, which are offered to Vajradaka who appears from a blazing fire to consume them. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/living-meaningfully-dying-joyfully">Living Meaningfully, Dying Joyfully</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajradhara"><strong>Vajradhara</strong> The founder of Vajrayana, or Tantra. He appears directly only to highly realized Bodhisattvas to whom he gives Tantric teachings. To benefit other living beings with less merit, he manifested in the more visible form of Buddha Shakyamuni. He also said that in degenerate times he would appear in an ordinary form as a Spiritual Guide. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajra-like-concentration"><strong>Vajra-like concentration</strong> The last moment of the Mahayana path of meditation. It is the antidote to the very subtle obstructions to omniscience. In the next moment, one attains the Mahayana Path of No More Learning, or Buddhahood.</p>
<p id="Vajra-Master"><strong>Vajra Master</strong> A fully qualified Tantric Spiritual Guide. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/great-treasury-of-merit">Great Treasury of Merit</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajrapani"><strong>Vajrapani</strong> The embodiment of the power of all the Buddhas. He appears in a wrathful aspect, displaying his power to overcome outer, inner, and secret obstacles. At the time of Buddha Shakyamuni he manifested as a Bodhisattva disciple in order to show Buddha’s disciples how to be perfect Mahayana disciples.</p>
<p id="Vajra posture"><strong>Vajra posture</strong> The perfect cross-legged posture. See also Seven-point posture of Vairochana. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajra-recitation"><strong>Vajra recitation</strong> A mantra recitation produced from inner winds that is practised in conjunction with Vajrayana practices. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajrasattva"><strong>Vajrasattva</strong> Buddha Vajrasattva is the aggregate of consciousness of all the Buddhas, appearing in the aspect of a white-coloured Deity specifically in order to purify sentient beings’ negativity. He is the same nature as Buddha Vajradhara, differing only in aspect. The practice of meditation and recitation of Vajrasattva is a very powerful method for purifying our impure mind and actions. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>:.</p>
<p id="Vajrayana"><strong>Vajrayana</strong> The Secret Mantra vehicle. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Secret-Mantra">Secret Mantra</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajrayana-Mahamudra"><strong>Vajrayana Mahamudra</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-k-o#Mahamudra">Mahamudra</a>.</p>
<p id="Vajrayogini"><strong>Vajrayogini</strong> A female Highest Yoga Tantra Deity who is the embodiment of indivisible bliss and emptiness. She is the same nature as Heruka. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Valid-cognizer/mind"><strong>Valid cognizer/mind</strong> A cognizer that is non-deceptive with respect to its engaged object. There are two types: inferential valid cognizers and direct valid cognizers. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Valid-mind"><strong>Valid mind</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-u-z#Valid-cognizer">Valid cognizer</a>.</p>
<p id="Vast-path"><strong>Vast path</strong> The vast path includes all the method practices from the initial cultivation of compassion through to the final attainment of the Form Body of a Buddha. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>.</p>
<p id="Vasubhandu"><strong>Vasubhandu</strong> A great Indian Buddhist scholar of the fifth century who was converted to the Mahayana by his older brother, Asanga. He wrote Treasury of Abhidharma (Skt. Abhidharmakosha).</p>
<p id="Vehicle/Spiritual vehicle"><strong>Vehicle/Spiritual vehicle</strong> An exalted awareness that leads to one’s final spiritual destination. See also Path/Spiritual path, Hinayana, Mahayana, and Vajrayana. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="View-of-the-transitory-collection"><strong>View of the transitory collection</strong> A type of self-grasping of persons that grasps one’s own I as being an inherently existent I. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Vinaya-Sutras"><strong>Vinaya Sutras</strong> Sutras in which Buddha principally explains the practice of moral discipline, and in particular the Pratimoksha moral discipline.</p>
<p id="Virtue"><strong>Virtue</strong> A phenomenon that functions as a main cause of happiness. It can refer to virtuous minds, virtuous actions, virtuous imprints, or the ultimate virtue of nirvana. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Virtuous-Tradition"><strong>Virtuous Tradition</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Gelugpa">Gelugpa</a>.</p>
<p id="Visual form"><strong>Visual form</strong> The object of eye awareness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a>.</p>
<p id="Vow"><strong>Vow</strong> A virtuous determination to abandon particular faults that is generated in conjunction with a traditional ritual. The three sets of vows are the Pratimoksha vows of individual liberation, the Bodhisattva vows, and the Secret Mantra or Tantric vows. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/the-bodhisattva-vow">The Bodhisattva Vow</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>.</p>
<p id="Wheel-of-Dharma"><strong>Wheel of Dharma</strong> Buddha gave his teachings in three main phases, which are known as ‘the three turnings of the Wheel of Dharma’. During the first Wheel he taught the four noble truths, during the second he taught the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras and revealed the Madhyamika-Prasangika view, and during the third he taught the Chittamatra view. These teachings were given according to the inclinations and dispositions of his disciples. Buddha’s final view is that of the second Wheel. Dharma is compared to the precious wheel, one of the possessions of a legendary chakravatin king. This wheel could transport the king across great distances in a very short time, and it is said that wherever the precious wheel travelled the king reigned. In a similar way, when Buddha revealed the path to enlightenment he was said to have ‘turned the Wheel of Dharma’ because, wherever these teachings are present, deluded minds are brought under control.</p>
<p id="Wheel of Life"><strong>Wheel of Life</strong> A diagram depicting the twelve dependent-related links and the four noble truths. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Winds"><strong>Winds</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Inner-winds">Inner winds</a>.</p>
<p id="Wisdom"><strong>Wisdom</strong> A virtuous, intelligent mind that makes its primary mind realize its object thoroughly. A wisdom is a spiritual path that functions to release our mind from delusions or their imprints. An example of wisdom is the correct view of emptiness. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/heart-of-wisdom">Heart of Wisdom</a> and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Wisdom-being"><strong>Wisdom being</strong> An actual Buddha, especially one who is invited to unite with a visualized commitment being.</p>
<p id="Wisdom-Truth-Body"><strong>Wisdom Truth Body</strong> Buddha’s omniscient mind. See also <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-p-t#Truth-Body">Truth Body</a>. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>, <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/tantric-grounds-and-paths">Tantric Grounds and Paths</a>, and <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/ocean-of-nectar">Ocean of Nectar</a></p>
<p id="Wishfulfilling-jewel"><strong>Wishfulfilling jewel</strong> A legendary jewel that, like Aladdin’s lamp, grants whatever is wished for.</p>
<p id="Wrong awareness"><strong>Wrong awareness</strong> A cognizer that is mistaken with respect to its engaged, or apprehended, object. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Wrong-view"><strong>Wrong view</strong> An intellectually-formed wrong awareness that denies the existence of an object that it is necessary to understand to attain liberation or enlightenment – for example, denying the existence of enlightened beings, karma, or rebirth. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/joyful-path-of-good-fortune">Joyful Path of Good Fortune</a>.</p>
<p id="Yama"><strong>Yama</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-u-z#Lord-of-Death">Lord of Death</a>.</p>
<p id="Yamantaka"><strong>Yamantaka</strong> A Highest Yoga Tantra Deity who is a wrathful manifestation of Manjushri.</p>
<p id="Yidam"><strong>Yidam</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-a-e#Deity">Deity</a>.</p>
<p id="Yoga"><strong>Yoga</strong> A term used for various spiritual practices that entail maintaining a special view, such as Guru yoga and the yogas of sleeping, rising, and experiencing nectar. ‘Yoga’ also refers to ‘union’, such as the union of tranquil abiding and superior seeing. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/guide-to-dakini-land">Guide to Dakini Land</a>.</p>
<p id="Yoga-Tantra"><strong>Yoga Tantra</strong> See <a href="http://kadampa.org/reference/glossary-of-buddhist-terms-f-j#Four-classes-of-Tantra">Four classes of Tantra</a>.</p>
<p id="Yogic direct perceiver"><strong>Yogic direct perceiver</strong> A direct perceiver that realizes a subtle object directly, in dependence upon its uncommon dominant condition, a concentration that is a union of tranquil abiding and superior seeing. See <a href="http://kadampa.org/books/understanding-the-mind">Understanding the Mind</a>.</p>
<p id="Yogi/Yogini "><strong>Yogi/Yogini</strong> Sanskrit words usually referring to a male or a female meditator who has attained the union of tranquil abiding and superior seeing.</p>
